title-group.article-title: Conscious Attention, Meditation, and Bilateral Information Transfer

article-meta.aff: 1Center for Neuropsychiatric Research of Traumatic Stress, Department of Psychiatry, First Faculty of Medicine, Charles University, Prague, Czech Republic
2Department of Clinical Psychology, The Chicago School of Professional Psychology, Chicago, IL, USA
3Advanced Clinical Neuroscience (Private Practice), Wheeling, IL, USA

author-notes.corresp: Petr Bob, Center for Neuropsychiatric Research of Traumatic Stress, Department of Psychiatry, First Faculty of Medicine, Charles University, Ke Karlovu 11, 128 00 Prague, Czech Republic. Email: petrbob@netscape.net

abstract.p: Recent findings indicate that conscious attention is related to large-scale information integration of various brain regions, including both hemispheres, that enables integration of parallel distributed modalities of processed information. There is also evidence that the level of information transference related to integration or splitting among brain regions, and between hemispheres, establishes a certain level of efficiency of the information processing. The level of information transference also may have modulatory influences on attentional capacity that are closely linked to the emotional arousal and autonomic response related to a stimulus. These findings suggest a hypothesis that changes in conscious attention, specifically during meditation could be reflected in the autonomic activity as the left–right information transference calculated from bilateral electrodermal activity (EDA). With the aim to compare conscious attention during meditation with other attentional states (resting state, Stroop task, and memory task), we performed bilateral EDA measurement in 7 healthy persons during resting state, Stroop task, neurofeedback memory test, and meditation. The results indicate that the information transference (ie, transinformation) is able to distinguish those attentional states, and that the highest level of the transinformation has been found during attentional processing related to meditation, indicating higher level of connectivity between left and right sides. Calculations other than pointwise transinformation (PTI) performed on EDA records, such as mean skin conductance level or laterality index, were not able to distinguish attentional states. The results suggest that PTI may present an interesting method useful for the assessment of information flow, related to neural functioning, that in the case of meditation may reflect typical integrative changes in the autonomic nervous system related to brain functions and focused attentional processing.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: According to recent findings, there is evidence that consciousness may integrate brain functions1–3 and might be a gateway to brain integration that enables access between otherwise separated neuronal functions.3 This influence of consciousness on brain integration may significantly change during various states of dissociated consciousness, in hypnosis,3 or during specific experiences such as meditation. This may significantly increase conscious awareness and focus attentional functions characterized by increased beta and gamma activity, reflecting increased brain synchrony and integration4–6 and also may influence brain plasticity and morphology.7,8

In this context, current empirical data suggest a hypothesis that, although various meditation practices have many culturally different forms, the different types of meditation likely have very similar neurophysiological correlates4 that could be related to increased brain synchrony and integration.4,5 Other recent data also suggest that meditation, like hypnosis through attentional mechanisms, may influence brain processing of incoming sensory stimuli and regulate underlying brain dynamics, such as interplay between cortical and subcortical structures and hemispheric interaction.5,6,9–12

Based on historical evidence, interhemispheric interactions play an important role in attentional functions13,14 and may present a general mechanism that the brain uses across different sensory modalities to increase processing efficiency and the load of processing between the 2 hemispheres.15,16 Interhemispheric interaction may dynamically allocate different computations involved in a complex task to each hemisphere by analogous mechanisms in parallel computers that dynamically distribute information processing.16,17

The level of information transference also may have modulatory influences on attentional capacity that are closely linked to emotional arousal and autonomic response related to a stimulus.18–20 These findings suggest that specific changes, related to states of conscious attention and arousal, could be reflected in autonomic activity as the left–right information transference calculated from bilateral measurement. With the aim to compare conscious attention during meditation with other attentional states, we performed bilateral EDA measurement, which is a sensitive indicator of laterality and interhemispheric interactions. It reflects the sympathetic axis of the autonomic nervous system, innervating dermal sweat glands and providing an index of emotional arousal and stress.21,22 Current evidence also shows that EDA is governed by ipsilateral limbic modulation influences, correlating with amygdala activity, but also with other bilateral structures, such as the ventromedial and dorsolateral prefrontal cortices, anterior cingulate gyrus, parietal lobe, insula, and hippocampus.21,23,24

These findings suggest a hypothesis that increased conscious attention during meditation could be linked to increased interhemispheric interactions, reflecting brain synchrony and heightened integrative brain functions5. Through limbic modulation, influences may be transferred into autonomic changes and reflected in left–right information transfer calculated from bilateral electrodermal measurement. The purpose of the present study is to compare the indices of left–right information transfer, calculated from bilateral EDA during meditation, and compare them with those of other states of conscious attention during Stroop stimuli and the memory task.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: For empirical examination of the suggested hypothesis, EDA recording and nonlinear data analysis were used in 7 healthy participants. The participants were 2 males and 5 females, average age of 28.54 ± 2.23 years, predominantly with university education. The study was approved by the university ethical committee, and all the participants gave written informed consent.

sec.title: EDA Measurement
sec.p: EDA was recorded bilaterally using a 2-channel SAM unit and Psylab software (Contact Precision Instruments, London, UK) connected to a personal computer with sampling frequency of 1000 Hz. The measurements were performed in a quiet room with a temperature of about 23°C. During the experiment, the participant sat in a comfortable chair. The measurement was performed using 2 pairs of Ag/AgCl electrodes (8 mm diameter active area filled with electroconductive paste) that were attached to the medial phalanges of the index and middle finger of each hand. EDA measurement was performed during rest, Stroop, neurofeedback memory and meditation; about 100 seconds of data were taken for calculations.

sec.title: Stroop Word–Color Test
sec.p: A well-known experimental approach to the neurophysiological study of attentional mechanisms is the Stroop word–color test.25 In a typical Stroop experiment, the participant is required to name the ink color which may be congruent (eg, red is printed in red ink) or incongruent (eg, red is printed in green ink). To perform the Stroop task, it is necessary to ignore the meaning of the printed word which may be especially difficult in cases of incongruent stimuli. This process is related to response inhibition, sensory rejection, and the Stroop task has been also used as a model of the stress defense reaction in humans.26 During administration of Stroop test 8, regularly changed congruent Stroop and incongruent Stroop stimuli were used (4 tables with words: green by green ink, red by red ink, blue by blue ink, yellow by yellow ink and 4 tables with words: green by red ink, red by green ink, blue by yellow ink, yellow by blue ink; both with regularly changing questions: “name the color” and “name the word”). The Stroop stimuli were presented on the computer screen at a distance of about 50 cm. Participants were required to complete all 8 words with a 5-second pause after each response.

sec.title: Neurofeedback Memory Test and Meditation
sec.p: To enhance conscious attention and self-reflective experience depending on mediated feedback, electroencephalography (EEG) standardized neurofeedback equipment (Neuroharmony, Braintech, Wheeling, IL, USA) with 2 frontal EEG electrodes (Fp1, Fp2 with reference to Fz) were used in the experiment. Neurofeedback consisted of visual and auditory information related to memory and meditation tasks.

Memorization training used various planets that appeared in sequence on the computer screen. A time period, for presenting a planet and the stimulus-related sound (“beep”), was regulated by a feedback mechanism related to increased alpha power (computed by Fourier analysis with a minimum of 30% power increase). Greater alpha power prolonged the planet presentation and sound duration. Participants were required to memorize the sequences in which planets appeared. They then had to choose, in sequence, the correct planets presented at the bottom of the screen. The first sequence began with 2 planets and this number increased to 9 planets. Each participant’s brain state determined the rate at which the planets were displayed. The planets appeared more quickly if participants did not satisfy the given conditions of the training mode. This task took approximately 4 minutes, and measured memorization based on how many sequences the participant chose correctly.

The meditation task required the participant to maintain a meditative state for approximately 4 minutes. The participants chose cartoon characters to represent themselves. While a repetitive, percussive beat played, the task required the participants to raise their character, who is depicted as sitting on a cloud, faster than the computer character sitting on a cloud on the right side of the screen. Below each participant’s cartoon character, a meter was displayed to represent the participant’s level of relaxation. When the participant was successful, the meter, reflecting alpha power, increased and the cartoon character was raised toward the top of the screen, and the beat changed to continuous sound. When the participant failed, their cartoon character showed a strained expression and began to sink to the bottom of the screen. The participants’ challenge was to raise their cartoon characters faster than the computer. When the task was complete, a lit coin represented how well the participant had focused during the 4 minutes.

sec.title: Data Analysis
sec.p: A practical approach to study complex dynamical systems is time series analysis. A postulate of this method is that every dynamic system, for example, the human brain and its functions, is governed and determined by a number of independent variables. Nevertheless, any real measurement performed on the system cannot provide information about all the variables because a system of high complexity such as the human brain is multidimensional. Time series analysis, therefore, represents a mathematical approximation that enables the reconstruction of certain variables underlying the multidimensional dynamics from the data obtained during the time.27 The data may provide, for example, a psychophysiological measurement performed during an experiment. Because observational data reflect only a few real independent variables of a system, approximation of the dynamic system behavior, therefore, uses a finite number of (mathematically reconstructed) variables to approximate states of the system or relationships between the subsystems. In this context, it is possible to use a measure of the mutual interaction and information flow between subsystems that may be computed in the phase space such as pointwise transinformation (PTI). This coupling measure also takes into account nonlinear dependencies and can be applied to nonstationary time. The PTI of 2 observable quantities has been derived from the Shannon information concept, and is calculated from the probability densities of the observables in the phase space.28,29 In practice, this is done by calculation of empirical point densities in the neighborhood of the reconstructed trajectory. Therefore, the values of the PTI depend on the selected search radius r, the range of PTI values is not normalized, and negative PTI values may occur in the experimental data. However, the increase or decrease in PTI level over time still provides information about changes in the coupling behavior of the investigated systems. The time resolution of the PTI is principally limited merely by the sampling rate and also enables study of very fast changes in the coupling behavior.28

The defining formula for the ith time step is
Y=I(δ,r,i)=log2Pix1x2(δ,r)Pix1(r)Pix2(r)
where the transinformation I is a function of the relative shift and relative phase space radius r, given for every sample point i. It denotes the probability to find a point of the reconstructed trajectory within a sphere of radius r around the ith phase space point and refers to the phase spaces of the time series x1 and x2.

In addition, we have calculated EDA values (skin conductance level) and also used left (L) and right (R) EDA values for calculation of the laterality index according to the usual formula30 LI = (L − R)/(L + R) to compare whether some specific changes also in EDA physiology related to left–right asymmetry during meditation and other attentional tasks will be found.

Statistical evaluation of PTI values (in bits) reflecting information transfer between left and right side, and laterality indices were performed using software package Statistica version 8.0 and included descriptive statistics, t test, and nonparametric test for dependent samples.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The results show that during meditation facilitated by self-reflective influence of neurofeedback, all the participants had the highest level of information transfer measured by PTI calculated between left and right EDA records. The statistical analysis also indicates that the values of PTI (in bits) statistically significantly distinguish all periods and tasks during measurement based on calculation for any left–right pair in all individual cases (Table 1). Statistical comparison using a nonparametric test for multiple comparison of dependent samples (Friedman analysis of variance) of averaged values of PTI shows that differences between periods of measurement are statistically significant at P < .00046 (Figure 1). This overall statistical analysis also shows that highest levels of PTI occur in the state of meditation.

caption.p: Mean values of pointwise transinformation (PTI) for the sample during the experimental periods.
Mean Values of Transinformation (PTI) for Each Individual Case During the Experimental Periods.a

fn.p: aAll the differences between experimental periods are statistically significant at P < .01.

sec.p: On the other hand, using analytical methods and calculations other than PTI performed on EDA records, such as mean skin conductance level or laterality index, were not able to distinguish the periods of attentional states.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Results of this study suggest that left–right information transfer calculated from bilateral electrodermal measurement may reflect autonomic changes related to brain synchrony, interhemispheric interactions, and changes in integrative brain functions that likely present a specific consequence of heightened conscious attention during meditation.5 The results support current empirical findings suggesting that neurophysiological correlates of meditation are related to increased brain synchrony and integration.4,5 Also these results and the PTI methodology support the hypothesis that various meditation practices could have very similar neurophysiological correlates.4 This increased brain synchrony may be related to increased alpha power which is localized mainly over frontal regions and occurs also during meditation related to biofeedback.4,31,32 These neurophysiological changes, related to meditation, are likely linked to achieve a “state” of open focus31 and self-transcending5 typical for changes of conscious attention during meditation.4 The results of this study suggest that increased alpha power during meditation, in comparison with memory testing is related to highly increased integration between left and right autonomic neural activities, reflecting the left and right ipsilateral modulatory influences of brain. This result may seem to be ambiguous because memory would not be expected to be enhanced by an open focus, as suggested by the finding that increased alpha power was rewarded for both the memory test and the meditation. In agreement with other reported data, this finding suggests that a certain quantitative level of alpha activity, and not only the presence of alpha activity per se, is a necessary criterion for its relationship to meditation and the state of open focus. Certain quantitatively defined values, indicating levels of alpha activity, may distinguish several states of consciousness.

Taken together these data, including results of this study, are in agreement with recent evidence indicating that neural correlates of various mental states related to perception, cognitive functions, and memory are based on various levels of information connectivity and integration.1–3 In this context, the influence of consciousness on neural integration likely explains the brain changes during various states of dissociated consciousness,17,35–37 in hypnosis,3 or during meditation.4,5,38 These changes may occur as a consequence of changes in attentional functions that, according to several data in the case of meditation, are characterized by increased beta and gamma activities reflecting increased brain synchrony.4–6,32–34 Based on these findings, meditation may be understood as a highly integrated state of consciousness related to high neuronal connectivity and integration, which likely lead to a decreased number of separated cognitive modules and subsystems. This increased connectivity may appear on various levels of neural processing and may also increase the load of bilateral processing between the 2 hemispheres,15,16,18 which likely allows dynamically connected information processing in the autonomic nervous system in a more integrated mode. With respect to this interpretation, the present study indicates that a higher level of mental and brain integration during meditation significantly influences autonomic activity that also works in a much more integrated form of neural processing.
